articles.headline: California Tax Revolt Faces a Retreat, 40 Years Later
articles.snippet: Proposition 13 in 1978 curbed property tax increases. Now voters may strip protection for commercial buildings, helping hard-hit local budgets.
articles.abstract: Proposition 13 in 1978 curbed property tax increases. Now voters may strip protection for commercial buildings, helping hard-hit local budgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In 1978, a Los Angeles businessman named Howard Jarvis led an insurgent campaign to pass Proposition 13, a ballot measure that limited California property taxes and inspired a nationwide tax revolt. The law has been considered sacrosanct ever since, something California governors and legislators challenge at their peril.

articles.headline: How Trump Maneuvered His Way Out of Trouble in Chicago
articles.snippet: When his skyscraper proved a disappointment, Donald Trump defaulted on his loans, sued his bank, got much of the debt forgiven — and largely avoided paying taxes on it.
articles.abstract: When his skyscraper proved a disappointment, Donald Trump defaulted on his loans, sued his bank, got much of the debt forgiven — and largely avoided paying taxes on it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial crisis was in full swing when Donald J. Trump traveled to Chicago in late September 2008 to mark the near-completion of his 92-floor skyscraper.
articles.byline: By David Enrich, Russ Buettner, Mike McIntire and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Trump Allies Amp Up Fight Over Tech’s Legal Shield Before Election
articles.snippet: Their animosity is likely to be on full display at a hearing on Wednesday with the leaders of Facebook, Google and Twitter.
articles.abstract: Their animosity is likely to be on full display at a hearing on Wednesday with the leaders of Facebook, Google and Twitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In September, the White House nominated a lawyer to be a commissioner on the Federal Communications Commission. One line on his résumé: aiding the administration’s push to limit an important legal shield for Silicon Valley companies.

articles.headline: Biden, Invoking F.D.R., Tries to Siphon Off Trump Voters in Georgia
articles.snippet: In the rural hills of Georgia, a state he is seeking to win, Joseph R. Biden Jr. called for “healing” and “restoration,” and a commitment to a common purpose to meet the challenges of the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: In the rural hills of Georgia, a state he is seeking to win, Joseph R. Biden Jr. called for “healing” and “restoration,” and a commitment to a common purpose to meet the challenges of the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARM SPRINGS, Ga. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. reached for political history on Tuesday as he swept into a red-state town with deep Democratic resonance and made a direct pitch to voters who flocked to President Trump in 2016, urging them to give him a chance to “heal” the country after a year of crippling crises.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Hospitals Are Reeling Under a 46 Percent Spike in Covid-19 Patients
articles.snippet: The number of people hospitalized with the coronavirus has climbed significantly from a month ago, straining cities that have fewer resources to weather the surges.
articles.abstract: The number of people hospitalized with the coronavirus has climbed significantly from a month ago, straining cities that have fewer resources to weather the surges.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The patient who died on Tuesday morning at Aurora St. Luke’s Medical Center was rolled out of her room under a white sheet. One nurse, fighting back tears, stood silently in the hall as the outline of the body passed by — one more death in an eight-month-old pandemic that has no end in sight.
articles.byline: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Simon Romero and Mike Baker

articles.headline: Kavanaugh’s Opinion in Wisconsin Voting Case Raises Alarms Among Democrats
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court justice’s suggestion that ballots arriving after Election Day could “flip the results” left voting rights activists concerned about how the court might rule in postelection fights.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court justice’s suggestion that ballots arriving after Election Day could “flip the results” left voting rights activists concerned about how the court might rule in postelection fights.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court decision on Monday barring the counting of mail-in ballots in Wisconsin that arrive after Election Day was not a surprise for many Democrats, who had pressed for it but expected to lose.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: A Podcast Answers a Fast-Food Question That Nobody Is Asking
articles.snippet: Intentionally inane, “Whatever Happened to Pizza at McDonald’s?” satirizes the business of podcasting.
articles.abstract: Intentionally inane, “Whatever Happened to Pizza at McDonald’s?” satirizes the business of podcasting.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there is a god of ludicrous ideas that later seem inspired, he must have smiled on Brian Thompson one evening four years ago. A comedy writer living in Los Angeles, Mr. Thompson had been bingeing on true crime podcasts when he decided to create a show that would plumb the stupidest, least consequential mystery he could imagine. For reasons he can’t fully explain, he came up with:

articles.headline: To Do Politics or Not Do Politics? Tech Start-Ups Are Divided
articles.snippet: Coinbase, Expensify, Soylent, Clubhouse and others are embroiled in a culture war over politics and the workplace.
articles.abstract: Coinbase, Expensify, Soylent, Clubhouse and others are embroiled in a culture war over politics and the workplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rob Rhinehart, a co-founder of nutritional drink start-up Soylent, declared in a blog post last week that he was supporting Kanye West for president.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: How the Surging Virus Has Crashed Into Campaigning in Every Imaginable Way
articles.snippet: The coronavirus pandemic is Issue No. 1, and it’s transformed everything about how this election season has played out.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus pandemic is Issue No. 1, and it’s transformed everything about how this election season has played out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Drive-through polling places. Candidates trying to sell themselves to voters on Zoom. Canvassers in masks and gloves knocking on doors and then scurrying six feet back.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Sarah Mervosh, Sydney Ember, Jacey Fortin and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Forget the Polls: This Chinese Indicator Is Flashing ‘Trump’
articles.snippet: The measure is unscientific at best. But merchants say sales of the president’s campaign merchandise at a major wholesale market are outstripping Biden’s.
articles.abstract: The measure is unscientific at best. But merchants say sales of the president’s campaign merchandise at a major wholesale market are outstripping Biden’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: YIWU, China — Deep inside a 10-block-long factory outlet mall in China, the people who supply Americans with their plastic dinosaurs and “Kiss My Bass” baseball caps are confident about a Nov. 3 victory for Donald Trump.

articles.headline: Social Security Seemed Like a Future Problem. The Virus Changed That.
articles.snippet: Even before the pandemic, Social Security’s finances were under growing pressure. The next president and Congress will play a crucial role in what happens next.
articles.abstract: Even before the pandemic, Social Security’s finances were under growing pressure. The next president and Congress will play a crucial role in what happens next.
articles.lead_paragraph: Social Security has always seemed like a future problem, with experts long predicting a benefits squeeze in the decades ahead. But the coronavirus has put tens of millions of Americans out of work, and economists are predicting that the recovery will take years.
